item.title: Secret Service in US Expands a Global Push Against Crypto Scams
item.description: The scam began with a message, then a friendly exchange. A stranger directed the victim to a cryptocurrency investment site that appeared professional — slick design, charts, even customer support. The first deposit showed a modest profit. So did the next. Encouraged, the victim sent more, even borrowing money to keep up. Then, without warning, the platform stopped responding. The account balance disappeared.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: Secret Service investigative analyst and technical advisor Jamie Lam teaching Bermuda police officers and prosecutors how to trace cryptocurrency funds at Police Headquarters in Prospect, Bermuda, on June 25.

item.title: Nvidia Partner Hon Hai Meets Sales Estimates on Strong AI Demand
item.description: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. reported 15.8% growth in quarterly sales on robust demand for AI servers and iPhones.
item.dc:creator: Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: The Foxconn Technology Co. booth at the Computex conference in Taipei, Taiwan, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. Computex kicked off Monday in Taipei, and as in years past drew industry chieftains from Nvidia Corp.'s Jensen Huang and Qualcomm Inc.'s Cristiano Amon to Young Liu of Foxconn, which makes the bulk of the world's iPhones and Nvidia servers. Photographer: Annabelle Chih/Bloomberg

item.title: US Plans AI Chip Curbs on Malaysia, Thailand Over China Concerns
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration plans to restrict shipments of AI chips from the likes of Nvidia Corp. to Malaysia and Thailand, part of an effort to crack down on suspected semiconductor smuggling into China.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins

item.title: Harvard Warns Foreign Students Over US Airport, Social Media
item.description: Harvard University staff advised international students to be cautious about social media posts and warned some groups against arriving at Boston’s Logan International Airport.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth, Emma Haidar, Brunella Tipismana Urbano

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.

item.title: Google to Propose Price-Comparison Box in Search to Appease EU
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Google will propose highlighting search results from other companies’ shopping and travel platforms at the top of its page in an attempt to comply with the European Union’s Digital Markets Act and fend off fines, people familiar the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Gian Volpicelli

item.title: Hip-Hop Musical Subverts Silicon Valley Founder Stereotypes
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Ellen Huet reports on a musical that puts a new spin on the myth of the Silicon Valley startup founder.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Huet

media:content.media:description: The Co-Founders musical examines Silicon Valley’s narratives around entrepreneurship.

item.title: Louis Vuitton Korea Suffers Cyberattack as Customer Data Leaked
item.description: Louis Vuitton Korea suffered a cyberattack that compromised some customer data, the second time in recent months that hackers have targeted the world’s largest luxury group.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom

item.title: SK Telecom Waives Cancellation Fees After Major Data Breach
item.description: SK Telecom Co. is waiving cancellation fees for customers who want to leave its network after South Korean authorities said the carrier should scrap the penalties following a major data breach.
item.dc:creator: Yoolim Lee

media:content.media:description: SK Telecom Co. headquarters in Seoul. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Main Grid Sees Renewables Trimming Chance of Blackouts
item.description: China’s record buildout of renewables may help networks overcome weather-driven demand spikes, according to the research arm of the country’s biggest grid operator.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Kathy Chen

media:content.media:description: The Dunhuang Photovoltaic Industrial Park in Dunhuang, Gansu Province, China.

item.title: British Library CEO: ‘Every Generation Has a Phase of Panic’
item.description: Rebecca Lawrence is more focused on securing new funding and dealing with the aftermath of a cyberattack than stressing about literacy and AI.
item.dc:creator: Mishal Husain
